chapter.title: Three steps to accessing accommodations
chapter.content:
Adult students can play a significant role in choosing and accessing accommodations.

In this topic, we will:

  • explain the difference between instructional accommodation and testing accommodation, and
  • describe the three essential steps each individual must take to gain access to accommodations:
    1. self-determination;
    2. self-disclosure, and
    3. self-advocacy.

chapter.title: What is the difference between instructional and testing accommodations?
chapter.content:
It is important to understand the distinction between instructional accommodation and testing accommodation. 

Instructional accommodations are accommodations made in the classroom based on the student's abilities, the student's results, and the instructor's assessment of the student’s situation, and the instructor’s best judgment. 

Testing accommodations refer to accommodations made for high-stakes tests such as the GED or college placement tests. These accommodations have restrictions and require more specific documentation before they can be implemented.

chapter.title: Self-determination requires learners to be proactive and persistent
chapter.content:
The first step to accessing accommodations is self-determination. This means that an individual has a productive yet realistic understanding of his or her strengths and weaknesses, and can choose a path in life that is satisfying and leads to success. 

The learner also recognizes that he or she may need some assistance in performing certain tasks. It is important to be able to ask for help and recognize when accommodations are needed. The concept of self-determination applies to us all, whether we have a disability or not. 

Self-determination requires the learner to:

  • plan for the future by setting goals and the steps required to achieve those goals;
  • be proactive by gaining support and taking advantage of resources to ensure success; and
  • reflect by evaluating differences between expected outcome, performance, and actual outcome, and then adjusting for next time.

chapter.title: Questions to gain self-awareness
chapter.content:
Self-determination requires learners to gain self-awareness as well as learn to value his or her self. Instructors may want to assist students with LD in gaining self-awareness by encouraging them to consider, discuss, or write their responses to these questions:

  • What are my areas of strength?
  • What is difficult for me?
  • What do I enjoy?
  • What is important to me?
  • How well do I understand my learning disability?
  • How can I explain my learning disability?

Knowing the answers to these questions helps individuals learn to value themselves by accepting one's strengths and weakness, and then take responsibility for both successes and failures.

chapter.title: Self-disclosure necessary for adults with LD
chapter.content:
The next step to accessing accommodations is self-disclosure. This is an important next step of self-determination. It is particularly important for individuals with LD. 

The act of self-disclosure usually means three things:

  1. accepting the disability,
  2. obtaining documentation, and
  3. revealing the disability to others. 

Self-disclosure could prevent a learning disability from being misinterpreted as a lack of competence; however, the decision to self-disclose should be made by each individual in light of his or her circumstances. 

Self-disclosure is necessary for an adult with LD in an ABE program because, in order to receive formal or testing accommodations, one must share personal information about his or her disability.  Adults must decide where, when, what, and how to disclose.  They must also must provide documentation that includes how the disability affects performance, as well as a list of reasonable accommodations. 

In a postsecondary setting, adults with LD should disclose their disability during the enrollment period to the disability services office that oversees accommodation requests. The school’s administration office can identify this office for learners and instructors. Review the rights and responsibilities of college students with learning disabilities for more information about disclosure in a postsecondary setting. Adult education programs in postsecondary and other settings may consider similar processes for encouraging learners to disclose disabilities.

Additionally, adult learners may disclose their LD to individual instructors in order to ensure they receive the appropriate instructional or testing accommodations within the classroom. Teachers have the responsibility to:

  • Allow students to disclose their disabilities in an appropriate and confidential setting.
  • Acknowledge the rights of students with dignity and respect.
  • Maintain the integrity of academic standards.
  • Maintain student confidentiality.
  • Provide reasonable instructional and/or testing accommodations.

chapter.title: Advantages of self-disclosure
chapter.content:
The advantages of self-disclosure are: 

  • accommodations,
  • support network,
  • improved self-advocacy, and
  • legal protection against discrimination. 

Despite these advantages, some adults choose not to self-disclose. Their reasons can vary from fear of a sense of exclusion, sense of weakness, or high evaluation costs to receive an official diagnosis.

chapter.title: Self-advocacy necessary for adults with LD
chapter.content:
The final step to accessing accommodations is self-advocacy. The ability to self-advocate goes beyond self-disclosure. Self-advocacy includes the individual's ability to understand the types of accommodations he or she needs, as well as the ability to convey to teachers, testing entities, and/or employers that specific accommodations are required.

For example, someone who has a documented learning disability may require audio assistance when taking an exam. This person should first inquire about his or her options in the classroom. If no in-class accommodations, such as headphones, are available then setting accommodations may be necessary, such as a change to another room for read-aloud options.

chapter.title: Importance of accessing accommodations
chapter.content:
Let's take a look at a case study to understand the importance of accommodations for adult learners.  

Layla

Layla was diagnosed with LD in ninth grade and received special education services  throughout her secondary schooling. She is a very talented artist who struggles in the ability to read and write. Unfortunately, she was never able to pass her high school graduation tests to receive a diploma. 

After working with a graphic artist for a few years, several opportunities for advancing her job were suggested by her employer. However, any advancement is dependent upon her ability to complete her GED and attend postsecondary schooling that leads to specialized credentials. 

In relation to self-awareness, Layla is very aware of her academic strengths and weaknesses. However, she demonstrates difficulties in explaining how her abilities could be accommodated such that postsecondary schooling would be possible for her. New advances in technology, such as text-to-speech and speech-to-text software might provide her with the tools for success.  

Layla has been able to disclose her reading and writing problems with her employer, and she has received positive feedback. Therefore, her ability to disclose her disabilities with service providers working to help her access accommodations in postsecondary education classes will seem more familiar to her. These service providers might also help her better understand her LD as she reviews with them her past and current psychological documentation.
